snippet: In a civil complaint, the United States attorney in Manhattan said that Douglas A. J. Latchford, a collector in Bangkok, bought a 10th-century statue knowing that it had been looted.
abstract: United States attorney's office in Manhattan files civil complaint against art collector Douglas A J Latchford, claiming that he bought a 10th-century Khmer warrior statue in early 1970s knowing it had been looted from a jungle temple during the Cambodian civil war; lawyers are trying to help Cambodia recover the multimillion-dollar artwork, which Sotheby's in New York is still hoping to sell.

byline.contributor: Ralph Blumenthal contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: In a civil complaint, the United States attorney in Manhattan said that Douglas A. J. Latchford, a collector in Bangkok, bought a 10th-century statue knowing that it had been looted.

headline.seo: Khmer-Art Collector Linked to Statue, U.S. Asserts
headline.main: Claims of Looting Shadow Expert in Khmer Art
headline.print_headline: Claims of Looting Shadow Expert in Khmer Art
